page.title: 04Amenities in Clifton
page.content: The school was built in 1850. It was able to accommodate 173 children. Today, there are only 43 5-8 year olds who attend the school. The children live in Clifton and the neighbouring parish of Newton. There is a V.G. grocer's shop,post office,picture framing gallery and a hairdressing salon.The mobile library visits the village once a fortnight. The Townsend Memorial Hall is used for many social functions,including meetings of the local history society. The church youth group meet in the church crypt.Various groups hire the school for activities as fencing and "keep-fit". Both the North Oxford Canal and the main London railway line skirt the edge of Clifton.Part of the dismantled railway line also crosses the northern fringe of the village.
